pli-tv-pvr4:1.3: how many matters is one trained in,
pli-tv-pvr4:1.6: how many matters is one trained in,
pli-tv-pvr4:1.11: how many things to be remembered,
pli-tv-pvr4:1.12: how many matters making for schism,
pli-tv-pvr4:2.3: five matters that are trained in,
pli-tv-pvr4:2.6: seven matters that are trained in,
pli-tv-pvr4:2.9: six matters that are trained in,
pli-tv-pvr4:3.1: Herein what are the five offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:3.2: An offence involving Defeat, an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order, an offence of Expiation, an offence to be Confessed, an offence of wrong-doing—
pli-tv-pvr4:4.1: Herein, what are the five classes of offence?
pli-tv-pvr4:4.2: The class of offence involving Defeat … the class of offence of wrong-doing—
pli-tv-pvr4:4.3: these are the five classes of offence. [3]
pli-tv-pvr4:5.1: Herein what are the five matters that are trained in?
pli-tv-pvr4:5.2: Abstaining from, refraining from, avoidance of, restraint from, not doing, not committing, non-trespassing, not transgressing control, bridge-breaking in regard to the five classes of offence—
pli-tv-pvr4:5.3: these are the five matters that are trained in. [4]
pli-tv-pvr4:6.1: Herein what are the seven offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:6.2: An offence involving defeat, an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order, a grave offence, an offence of Expiation, an offence to be Confessed, an offence of wrong-doing, an offence of wrong-speech—
pli-tv-pvr4:7.1: Herein what are the seven classes of offence?
pli-tv-pvr4:7.2: The class of offence involving Defeat … the class of offence of wrong-speech—
pli-tv-pvr4:7.3: these are the seven classes of offence. [6]
pli-tv-pvr4:8.1: Herein what are the seven matters that are trained in?
pli-tv-pvr4:8.2: Abstaining from … bridge-breaking in regard to the seven classes of offence—
pli-tv-pvr4:8.3: these are the seven matters that are trained in. [7]
pli-tv-pvr4:9.1: Herein what are the six (kinds of) disrespect?
pli-tv-pvr4:9.2: Disrespect for the Buddha, disrespect for _Dhamma_, disrespect for the Order, disrespect for the training, disrespect for diligence, disrespect for reciprocal courtesy—
pli-tv-pvr4:9.3: these are the six (kinds of) disrespect. [8]
pli-tv-pvr4:10.1: Herein what are the six (kinds of) respect?
pli-tv-pvr4:10.2: Respect for the Buddha … respect for reciprocal courtesy—
pli-tv-pvr4:10.3: these are the six (kinds of) respect. [9]
pli-tv-pvr4:11.1: Herein what are the six matters that are trained in?
pli-tv-pvr4:11.2: Abstaining from … bridge-breaking in regard to the six (kinds of) disrespect—
pli-tv-pvr4:11.3: these are the six matters that are trained in. [10]
pli-tv-pvr4:12.1: Herein what are the four fallings away?
pli-tv-pvr4:12.2: Falling away from moral habit, falling away from good behaviour, falling away from (right) view, falling away from (right) mode of livelihood—
pli-tv-pvr4:12.3: these are the four fallings away. [11]
pli-tv-pvr4:13.1: Herein what are the six origins of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:13.2: There is an offence that originates from body, not from speech, not from mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.3: there is an offence that originates from speech, not from body, not from mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.4: there is an offence that originates from body and from speech, not from mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.5: there is an offence that originates from body and from mind, not from speech;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.6: there is an offence that originates from speech and from mind, not from body;
pli-tv-pvr4:13.7: there is an offence that originates from body and from speech and from mind—
pli-tv-pvr4:13.8: these are the six origins of offences. [12]
pli-tv-pvr4:14.1: Herein what are the six roots of disputes?
pli-tv-pvr4:14.2: As to this a monk becomes angry and bears ill-will.
pli-tv-pvr4:14.3: Whatever monk becomes angry and bears ill-will, he lives without deference, disrespectful towards the Teacher … (= Kd.14.14.3 pli-tv-kd14:14.3.1 _down to the end of that paragraph. The word monk is here constantly omitted_) …
pli-tv-pvr4:15.11: thus there come to be no future effects of that evil root of disputes—
pli-tv-pvr4:15.12: these are the six roots of disputes. [13]
pli-tv-pvr4:16.1: Herein what are the six roots of censure?
pli-tv-pvr4:16.2: As to this a monk becomes angry … (_this is identical with the last paragraph, reading censure instead of dispute_) …
pli-tv-pvr4:17.12: —these are the six roots of censure. [14]
pli-tv-pvr4:18.1: Herein what are the six things to be remembered?
pli-tv-pvr4:18.2: As to this, a monk should offer his fellow Brahma-farers a friendly act of body both in public and in private.
pli-tv-pvr4:18.3: This is a thing to be remembered making for affection, making for respect, it conduces to concord, to lack of dispute, to harmony, to unity.
pli-tv-pvr4:19.1: And again a monk should offer … a friendly act of speech …
pli-tv-pvr4:21.1: And again, whatever are those lawful acquisitions, lawfully acquired, if they be even but what is put into the begging bowl—a monk should be one to enjoy sharing such acquisitions, to enjoy them in common with his virtuous fellow Brahma-farers.
pli-tv-pvr4:21.2: This too is a thing to be remembered … to unity.
pli-tv-pvr4:22.1: And again, whatever are those moral habits that are faultless, without flaw, spotless, without blemish, freeing, praised by wise men, untarnished, conducive to concentration— a monk should dwell united in virtues such as these with his fellow Brahma-farers, both in public and in private.
pli-tv-pvr4:22.2: This too is a thing to be remembered … to unity.
pli-tv-pvr4:23.1: And again, whatever view is ariyan, leading onwards, leading him who acts according to it to the complete destruction of anguish—a monk should dwell united in a view such as this with his fellow Brahma-farers, both in public and in private.
pli-tv-pvr4:23.2: This too is a thing to be remembered … to unity.
pli-tv-pvr4:24.1: Herein what are the eighteen matters making for schism?
pli-tv-pvr4:24.2: As to this, a monk explains non-_dhamma_ as _Dhamma_ … (= Kd.10.5.4 pli-tv-kd10:5.4.1) … he explains not a very bad offence as a very bad offence—
pli-tv-pvr4:24.3: these are the eighteen matters making for schism. [16]
pli-tv-pvr4:25.1: Herein what are the four legal questions?
pli-tv-pvr4:25.2: A legal question concerning disputes, a legal question concerning censure, a legal question concerning offences, a legal question concerning obligations—
pli-tv-pvr4:25.3: these are the four legal questions. [17]
pli-tv-pvr4:26.1: Herein what are the seven decidings?
pli-tv-pvr4:26.2: A verdict in the presence of, a verdict of innocence, a verdict of past insanity, a carrying out on (his) acknowledgement, a decision of the majority, a decision for specific depravity, a covering over (as) with grass—
pli-tv-pvr4:27.1: Concluded is the Chapter on the Questions: “How Many?”
pli-tv-pvr4:30.5: Just seven decidings are spoken of:
pli-tv-pvr4:31.1: Could one fall into an offence involving Defeat by means of the first origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:31.3: Could one fall into an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order?
pli-tv-pvr4:31.5: Could one fall into a grave offence …
pli-tv-pvr4:31.13: Could one fall into an offence of wrong speech?
pli-tv-pvr4:32.1: Could one fall into … (_see_ Prv.4.2.1 pli-tv-pvr4:31.1) …
pli-tv-pvr4:32.7: an offence of Expiation by means of the second origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:32.9: Could one fall into an offence to be Confessed?
pli-tv-pvr4:32.11: Could one fall into an offence of wrong-doing?
pli-tv-pvr4:32.13: Could one fall into an offence of wrong speech?
pli-tv-pvr4:33.1: Could one fall into … (= Prv.4.2.1 pli-tv-pvr4:31.1) … by means of the third origin of offences? … [3]
pli-tv-pvr4:34.1: Could one fall into an offence involving Defeat by means of the fourth origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:34.3: Could one fall into an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order … (= Prv.4.2.1 pli-tv-pvr4:31.1) [4]
pli-tv-pvr4:35.1: Could one fall into … (= Prv.4.2.4 pli-tv-pvr4:34.1) …
pli-tv-pvr4:35.9: an offence to be Confessed by means of the fifth origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:35.11: Could one fall into an offence of wrong-doing?
pli-tv-pvr4:35.13: Could one fall into an offence of wrong speech?
pli-tv-pvr4:36.1: Could one fall … by means of the sixth origin of offences? … (= Prv.4.2.4 pli-tv-pvr4:34.1). [6]
pli-tv-pvr4:37.1: Concluded is the First Chapter: on the six Origins of Offences
pli-tv-pvr4:38.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the first origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:38.2: One falls into five offences by means of the first origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:38.3: A monk, thinking it is allowable, begging himself, builds a hut without the site being marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it; in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:38.4: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:38.5: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:38.6: A monk, thinking it is allowable, eats a meal at a wrong time—there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:38.7: A monk, thinking it is allowable, eats solid food or soft food, having accepted it with his own hand from the hand of nun who is not a relation (and) has entered among the houses—there is an offence to be Confessed.
pli-tv-pvr4:38.8: One falls into these five offences by means of the first origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.2: Of the seven classes of offence in how many classes of offence are they comprised?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.3: Of the six origins of offences by how many origins do they originate?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.4: Of the four legal questions which legal question?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.5: Of the seven decidings by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:39.6: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:39.7: it may be to falling away from moral habit, it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.8: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in five classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:39.9: it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence to be Confessed; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.10: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:39.11: they originate by body, not by speech, not by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.12: Of the four legal questions the legal question concerning offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:39.13: Of the seven decidings they are stopped by three decidings:
pli-tv-pvr4:39.14: it may be by a verdict in the presence of and by the carrying out on (his) acknowledgement; it may be by a verdict in the presence of and by a covering over (as) with grass. [1]
pli-tv-pvr4:40.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the second origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:40.2: One falls into four offences by means of the second origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:40.3: A monk, thinking it is allowable commands
pli-tv-pvr4:40.5: If they build a hut for him, the site not having been marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it,
pli-tv-pvr4:40.6: in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:40.7: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:40.8: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:40.9: A monk, thinking it is allowable, makes someone who is not ordained teach _Dhamma_ line by line, there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:40.10: One falls into these four offences by means of the second origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:41.1: Of the four fallings away how many … (_see_ Prv.4.3.1 pli-tv-pvr4:38.1) …
pli-tv-pvr4:41.2: by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:41.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:41.4: it may be to falling away from moral habit, it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:41.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in four classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:41.6: it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:41.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:41.8: they originate by speech, not by body not by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:41.9: Of the four legal questions the legal question concerning offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:41.10: Of the seven decidings they are stopped by three decidings:
pli-tv-pvr4:41.11: … (_see_ Prv.4.3.1 pli-tv-pvr4:38.1) … and by a covering over (as) with grass. [2]
pli-tv-pvr4:42.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the third origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:42.2: One falls into five offences by means of the third origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:42.3: A monk, thinking it is allowable, having settled on (a site), builds a hut, the site not having been marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it;
pli-tv-pvr4:42.4: in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:42.5: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:42.6: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:42.7: A monk, thinking it is allowable, having asked for sumptuous foods for himself, eats them, there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:42.8: A monk, thinking it is allowable, without restraining nuns who are giving directions, eats, there is an offence to be Confessed.
pli-tv-pvr4:42.9: One falls into these five offences by means of the third origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:43.1: Of the four fallings away how many …
pli-tv-pvr4:43.2: by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:43.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away
pli-tv-pvr4:43.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in five classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:43.6: it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one, it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence to be Confessed; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:43.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:43.8: they originate by body and by speech, not by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:43.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [3]
pli-tv-pvr4:44.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the fourth origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:44.3: A monk indulges in sexual intercourse, there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.4: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, begging himself, builds a hut without the site being marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it; in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:44.5: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:44.6: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.7: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, eats a meal at a wrong time—there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.8: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, eats solid food or soft food, having accepted it with his own hand from the hand of a nun who is not a relation (and) has entered among the houses—there is an offence to be Confessed.
pli-tv-pvr4:44.9: One falls into these six offences by means of the fourth origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:45.1: Of the four fallings away how many …
pli-tv-pvr4:45.2: by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:45.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away
pli-tv-pvr4:45.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in six classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:45.6: it may be in the class of offence involving Defeat; it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence to be Confessed; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:45.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:45.8: they originate by body and by mind, not by speech.
pli-tv-pvr4:45.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [4]
pli-tv-pvr4:46.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the fifth origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:46.3: A monk of evil wishes, overcome by desire, claims a non-existent state of further-men which is not fact—there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr4:46.4: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, commands
pli-tv-pvr4:46.6: If they build a hut for him, the site not having been marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it,
pli-tv-pvr4:46.7: in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:46.8: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:46.9: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:46.10: A monk thinking it is not allowable, makes someone who is not ordained teach _Dhamma_ line by line, there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:46.11: If, not desiring to jeer at, not desiring to scoff at, not desiring to shame, (but having) a fondness for joking, he speaks of a low thing in low (words), there is an offence of wrong speech.
pli-tv-pvr4:46.12: One falls into these six offences by means of the fifth origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:47.2: by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:47.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away
pli-tv-pvr4:47.5: of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in six classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:47.6: it may be in the class of offence involving Defeat; it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing; it may be in the class of offence of wrong speech.
pli-tv-pvr4:47.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:47.8: they originate by speech and by mind, not by body.
pli-tv-pvr4:47.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [5]
pli-tv-pvr4:48.1: How many offences does one fall into by means of the sixth origin of offences?
pli-tv-pvr4:48.3: A monk, having arranged together (with others), steals the goods, there is an offence involving Defeat.
pli-tv-pvr4:48.4: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, having arranged, builds a hut, the site not having been marked out, exceeding the measure, involving destruction, not with an open space round it—in the action there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:48.5: if one lump is still to come there is a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:48.6: when that lump has come there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order.
pli-tv-pvr4:48.7: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, having asked for sumptuous foods for himself, eats them, there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:48.8: A monk, thinking it is not allowable, without restraining nuns who are giving directions, eats, there is an offence to be Confessed.
pli-tv-pvr4:48.9: One falls into these six offences by means of the sixth origin of offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:49.1: Of the four fallings away how many …
pli-tv-pvr4:49.5: by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:49.6: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away
pli-tv-pvr4:49.8: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in six classes … (_see_ Prv.4.3.4 pli-tv-pvr4:44.1)
pli-tv-pvr4:49.9: … it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:49.10: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:49.11: they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:49.14: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [6]
pli-tv-pvr4:50.2: Concluded is the Second Chapter: on How Many Offences for the six Originations of Offences
pli-tv-pvr4:51.1: Bodily origins have been proclaimed for the world’s welfare by Him who had vision of the infinite, vision of aloofness;
pli-tv-pvr4:51.3: By this means how many offences have originated?
pli-tv-pvr4:51.4: I ask this—explain, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:52.1: Bodily origins have been explained for the world’s welfare by Him who had vision of the infinite, vision of aloofness;
pli-tv-pvr4:52.3: By this means five offences have originated:
pli-tv-pvr4:52.4: I explain this to you, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:53.1: Verbal origins have been proclaimed for the world’s welfare
pli-tv-pvr4:53.4: … explain, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:54.1: Verbal origins have been explained for the world’s welfare …
pli-tv-pvr4:54.4: I explain this to you, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:55.1: Bodily, verbal origins have been proclaimed …
pli-tv-pvr4:56.1: Bodily, verbal origins have been proclaimed …
pli-tv-pvr4:61.1: Bodily, verbal, mental origins have been proclaimed for the world’s welfare by Him who had vision of the infinite, vision of aloofness;
pli-tv-pvr4:61.3: By this means how many offences have originated?
pli-tv-pvr4:61.4: I ask this—explain, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:62.1: Bodily, verbal, mental origins have been proclaimed for the world’s welfare by Him who had vision of the infinite, vision of aloofness;
pli-tv-pvr4:62.3: By this means six offences have originated:
pli-tv-pvr4:62.4: I explain this to you, (thou who art) skilled in the Analyses.
pli-tv-pvr4:63.1: Concluded is the Third Talk: on the Origin of Offences
pli-tv-pvr4:64.1: Because of falling away from moral habit how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:64.2: Because of falling away from moral habit one falls into four offences:
pli-tv-pvr4:64.3: a nun who knowing of a matter involving Defeat conceals it, falls into an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr4:64.4: if, being in doubt, she conceals it, she falls into a grave offence.
pli-tv-pvr4:64.5: If a monk conceals an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order he falls into an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:64.6: If he conceals his own very bad offence he falls into an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:64.7: Because of falling away from moral habit one falls into these four offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:65.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:65.4: it may be to falling away from moral habit; it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in four classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:65.6: it may be in the class of offence involving Defeat; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:65.8: they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:65.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [1]
pli-tv-pvr4:66.1: Because of falling away from good behaviour how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:66.3: if one conceals a falling away from good behaviour one falls into an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:66.4: Because of falling away from good behaviour one falls into this one offence.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away does this offence appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:67.2: of the seven decidings by how many decidings is it stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:67.3: Of the four fallings away this offence appertains to one falling away:
pli-tv-pvr4:67.4: to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.5: Of the seven classes of offence it is comprised in one class of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:67.6: in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.7: Of the six origins of offences it originates by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:67.8: it originates by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.9: Of the four legal questions, the legal question concerned with offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:67.10: Of the seven decidings it is stopped by three decidings
pli-tv-pvr4:67.11: … and a covering over (as) with grass. [2]
pli-tv-pvr4:68.1: Because of falling away from (right) view how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:68.3: if one does not give up a depraved view though being admonished up to the third time, as a result of the motion there is an offence of wrong-doing;
pli-tv-pvr4:68.4: at the end of the resolutions there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:68.5: Because of falling away from (right) view one falls into these two offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:69.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:69.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to one falling away:
pli-tv-pvr4:69.4: to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:69.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in two classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:69.6: it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:69.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:69.8: they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:69.11: and by a covering over (as) grass. [3]
pli-tv-pvr4:70.1: Because of falling away from a (right) mode of livelihood how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:70.3: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood one of evil wishes, overcome by desire, claims a non-existent state of further-men which is not fact—there is an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.4: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood if one acts as a go-between there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.5: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood if one speaks saying “Whatever monk lives in your _vihāra_ is an arahant” there is a grave offence involving recognition;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.6: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood if a monk, having asked for sumptuous foods for himself, eats them, there is an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.7: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood if a nun, having asked for sumptuous foods for herself, partakes of them, there is an offence to be Confessed;
pli-tv-pvr4:70.8: for the sake of livelihood, for the reason of livelihood if one who is not ill, having asked for curry or conjey for himself, eats it, there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:70.9: Because of falling away from (right) mode of livelihood one falls into these six offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:71.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:71.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:71.4: it may be to falling away from moral habit; it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:71.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in six classes of offence … (_see_ Prv.4.3.4 pli-tv-pvr4:44.1 _above_) …
pli-tv-pvr4:71.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of the six origins:
pli-tv-pvr4:71.8: it may be that they originate by body, not by speech, not by mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.9: it may be that they originate by speech, not by body, not by mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.10: it may be that they originate by body and by speech, not by mind;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.11: it may be that they originate by body and by mind, not by speech;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.12: it may be that they originate by speech and by mind, not by body;
pli-tv-pvr4:71.13: it may be that they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:71.16: and a covering over (as) with grass. [4]
pli-tv-pvr4:72.1: Concluded is the Fourth Chapter: on Because of Falling Away
pli-tv-pvr4:73.1: Because of legal questions concerning disputes how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:73.2: Because of legal questions concerning disputes one falls into two offences:
pli-tv-pvr4:73.3: if one insults one who is ordained there is an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr4:73.4: if one insults one who is not ordained there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:73.5: Because of legal questions concerning disputes one falls into these two offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:74.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:74.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to one falling away:
pli-tv-pvr4:74.4: to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:74.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in two classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:74.6: it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:74.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of three origins:
pli-tv-pvr4:74.8: it may be that they originate by body and by mind, not by speech;
pli-tv-pvr4:74.9: it may be that they originate by speech and mind, not by body;
pli-tv-pvr4:74.10: it may be that they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:74.13: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [1]
pli-tv-pvr4:75.1: Because of legal questions concerning censure how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:75.3: if one defames a monk with an unfounded charge of an offence involving Defeat, there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr4:75.4: if one defames with an unfounded charge of an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order, there is an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr4:75.5: if one defames with an unfounded charge of falling away from good behaviour there is an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:75.6: Because of legal questions concerning censure one falls into these three offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:76.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:76.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:76.4: it may be to falling away from moral habit; it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:76.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in three classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:76.6: it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:76.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of three origins:
pli-tv-pvr4:76.8: it may be that they originate by body and by mind, not by speech;
pli-tv-pvr4:76.9: it may be that they originate by speech and by mind, not by body;
pli-tv-pvr4:76.10: it may be that they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:76.13: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [2]
pli-tv-pvr4:77.1: Because of legal questions concerning offences how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:77.3: a nun who, knowing of a matter involving Defeat, conceals it, falls into an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr4:77.4: if, being in doubt, she conceals it, she falls into a grave offence;
pli-tv-pvr4:77.5: if a monk conceals an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order
pli-tv-pvr4:77.6: he falls into an offence of Expiation;
pli-tv-pvr4:77.7: if he conceals a falling away from good behaviour he falls into an offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:77.8: Because of legal questions concerning offences one falls into these four offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:78.3: Of the four fallings away these offences appertain to two fallings away:
pli-tv-pvr4:78.4: it may be to falling away from moral habit; it may be to falling away from good behaviour.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in four classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:78.6: it may be in the class of offence involving Defeat; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.7: Of the six origins of offence they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:78.8: they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:78.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [3]
pli-tv-pvr4:79.1: Because of legal questions concerning obligations how many offences does one fall into?
pli-tv-pvr4:79.3: if a nun, an imitator of one who has been suspended, though being admonished up to the third time does not give up (her course), as a result of the motion there is an offence of wrong-doing,
pli-tv-pvr4:79.4: as a result of two resolutions there are grave offences,
pli-tv-pvr4:79.5: at the end of the resolutions there is an offence involving Defeat;
pli-tv-pvr4:79.6: if monks who are imitators of a schismatic, though being admonished up to the third time, do not give up (their course), there is an offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order;
pli-tv-pvr4:79.7: if one, though being admonished up to the third time, does not give up depraved views there is an offence of Expiation.
pli-tv-pvr4:79.8: Because of legal questions concerning obligations one falls into these five offences.
pli-tv-pvr4:80.1: Of the four fallings away how many fallings away do these offences appertain to …
pli-tv-pvr4:80.5: Of the seven classes of offence they are comprised in five classes of offence:
pli-tv-pvr4:80.6: it may be in the class of offence involving Defeat; it may be in the class of offence requiring a Formal Meeting of the Order; it may be in the class of offence that is a grave one; it may be in the class of offence of Expiation; it may be in the class of offence of wrong-doing.
pli-tv-pvr4:80.7: Of the six origins of offences they originate by means of one origin:
pli-tv-pvr4:80.8: they originate by body and by speech and by mind.
pli-tv-pvr4:80.11: and by a covering over (as) with grass. [4]
pli-tv-pvr4:81.1: Leaving aside the seven offences, the seven classes of offence—of the four fallings away how many fallings away do the remaining offences appertain to?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.2: Of the seven classes of offence in how many classes of offence are they comprised?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.3: Of the six origins of offences by how many origins do they originate?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.4: Of the four legal questions which legal question?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.5: Of the seven decidings by how many decidings are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.6: Leaving aside the seven offences, the seven classes of offence—it is not: of the four fallings away to which falling away do the remaining offences appertain,
pli-tv-pvr4:81.7: of the seven classes of offence in which class of offence are they comprised,
pli-tv-pvr4:81.8: of the six origins of offences by which origin do they originate,
pli-tv-pvr4:81.9: of the four legal questions which legal question,
pli-tv-pvr4:81.10: of the seven decidings by which deciding are they stopped?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.11: What is the reason for that?
pli-tv-pvr4:81.12: Leaving aside the seven offences and the seven classes of offence there are no other offences. [5]
pli-tv-pvr4:82.1: Concluded is the Fifth Chapter: on Because of Legal Questions
pli-tv-pvr4:85.4: and so too about legal questions.
